settings.text_5: Experience the difference in every detail

settings.title: Purposeful Prints
settings.subheading: A Conversation Starter Between You And Your Little One

settings.title: How to: 3 easy steps
settings.text:
1. Point to characters and notice together
    Show and tell: point to a character or detail and say it aloud.
    “Owl.” “Orca.” “Frog.” “Moon.”

  2. Ask and imagine to spark curiosity
    Use open-ended prompts to invite a story.
    “What would you name the pika?” “Where is the otter going?” “Who is the owl visiting?”

  3. Play, connect, and grow
    Make the sounds, copy the moves, count what you see.
    “Hoot-hoot!” “Can you jump like the frog?” “Let’s count the fish.”

settings.text_1:
Point, name, and notice.

Short sounds & big expressions.
settings.text_2:
Find and label.

“Show me the owl.”

“Touch the flower.”
settings.text_3:
Build tiny stories.

“What happens next?”

“Who’s the frog meeting?”

settings.heading: How I use Kolorful prints with my kids
settings.text:
“I ask Isla what she’s wearing and she won’t say ‘a romper.’ She’ll squeal, ‘Otters!’ and we discover the baby otter on the mama’s belly together. And yes… I melt every single time. These tiny moments where we slow down and really see something together — that’s what Kolorful is all about.”
- Lian, Founder

settings.title: Owl
settings.text:
Owls soaring across the night sky and mama opossum with her brood skittering around invite cozy moments of storytelling and connection.

0–12 Months

  • Point and name: “Owl!”
  • Soft sounds: “Hoot-hoot.”
  • Trace the wings slowly to calm and connect.

12–24 Months

  • Imagination: “Is the owl flying or resting?”
  • Comparison: “Which owl is higher?”
  • Descriptive Language: “Where is the moon?”

2T–5T

  • Imagination: “What do you think the owl is watching from its perch?”
  • Problem Solving: “How could the baby opposums get down off mama?”
  • Emotional Awareness: “How do you think the baby owl feels with mama nearby?”

settings.title: Pika
settings.text:
Playful pikas, purple mountains, and swooping birds spark curiosity and conversation.

0–12 Months

  • Point and label: “Pika!”
  • Touch object: “Flower… soft.”
  • Simple colors: “Purple mountain.”

12–24 Months

  • Descriptive Language: “What is the pika holding?”
  • Comparison: “Which mountain is taller?”
  • Problem Solving: “How can the bird get over the peaks?”

2T–5T

  • Imagination: “Where is the pika taking that flower?”
  • Emotional Awareness: “Does the pika look curious or happy?”
  • Problem Solving: “If you were the bird, where would you fly next?”

settings.title: Orca
settings.text:
Mama and baby orcas gliding through colorful currents offer gentle, rhythmic talking moments.

0–12 Months

  • Sway together: “Swim, swim.”
  • Point to relationships: “Mama… baby.”
  • Splash sounds: “Shhhh… splash.”

12–24 Months

  • Comparison: “More fish or more seaweed?”
  • Descriptive Language: “What color is this fish?”
  • Problem Solving: “How can the baby orca catch up?”

2T–5T

  • Imagination: “Where are the orcas swimming today?”
  • Emotional Awareness: “How do you think they feel swimming together?”
  • Storytelling: “What happens in the ocean next?”

settings.title: Otter
settings.text:
Playful otters floating and snacking create perfect opportunities for giggles and empathy.

0–12 Months

  • Name characters: “Otter!” “Crab!”
  • Gentle rocking: “Float…”
  • Tap shells: “Snack!”

12–24 Months

  • Descriptive Language: “What is the otter holding?”
  • Comparison: “Which otter is closer to the crab?”
  • Movement: “Can you wiggle like the otter?”

2T–5T

  • Imagination: “What game are the otters playing?”
  • Problem Solving: “How will the otter open the shell?”
  • Emotional Awareness: “Do they look playful or peaceful today?”

settings.title: Frog
settings.text:
Leaping frogs, drifting leaves, and fluttering moths bring energy and expression to everyday moments.

0–12 Months

  • Frog sound play: “Ribbit!”
  • Gentle finger hops.
  • Point to leaves: “Leaf… falling.”

12–24 Months

  • Comparison: “Which lily pad is bigger?”
  • Descriptive Language: “Find something green.”
  • Counting: “How many frogs?”

2T–5T

  • Imagination: “Where will the frog hop next?”
  • Problem Solving: “How can the frog get to that lily pad?”
  • Emotional Awareness: “Does this frog look silly or serious?”
